title: About Me
text:
Bio
Hello everyone! I’m Moran Guo, a current ScM student studying biostatistics at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. I graduated from University of Rochester with a B.S. in Biological Sciences: Computational Biology (Magna Cum Laude) and minors in Mathematics & Japanese. During my last two years of undergraduate study, I researched protein coevolution and protein folding, utilizing AlphaFold and Bayesian Graphical Models to investigate correlated mutations. Moving forward, I’m eager to explore all possibilities in the field of biostatistics, with a particular interest in causal inference and Bayesian methods.
Outside of academics, I’m also a huge fan of rock climbing (especially bouldering) and working out. My home gym is Movement Hampden. I just recovered from a moderate ankle sprain. Besides that, I also enjoy pop Japanese culture, electronic music and watching tennis. In the near future, I might consider taking up squash or golf—or maybe both!

title: Example Analysis
text:
For this part of the project, I will use R’s iris dataset (built-in dataset in R) to perform a sample data anlysis.




A sample picture of the species Iris virginica. Photo Credit: Frank Mayfield





Intuitively speaking, different flowers (or species) have different sizes of sepal and petal. For this analysis, I analyzed the distribution of sepal and petal dimensions across different iris species in the iris dataset. Specifically, I aim to answer: Are there significant differences in petal and sepal dimensions among the species in the dataset?



Biologists, botanists, and enthusiastic data science students. Since the iris dataset is idea for k-means clustering and Principle Component Analysis (PCA), it is also an option for practicing classification algorithms.



The Iris dataset is a famous dataset built and used by biologist Ronald Fisher (Wikipedia 2024). He documented and used these data in his paper discussing Linear Discriminant Analysis (Fisher 1936). It consists of 50 samples from the three species of Iris: Iris setosa, Iris virginica, and Iris versicolor.
Link to the dataset: UCI Dataset Archive

I used knitr::kable() function to display tables with enhanced aesthetics in the website.

title: Example Analysis
text:
Data Wrangling
We first create a new variable Petal.Ratio, which is cauculated by dividing the Petal.Length by corresponding Petal.Width. Then, we calculate the average value of the Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, and Petal.Ratio across the three species.

suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(dplyr))
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(knitr)

iris_summary <- iris %>%
  mutate(Petal.Ratio = Petal.Length / Petal.Width)

iris_statistics <- iris_summary %>%
  group_by(Species) %>%
  summarize(
    Mean_Sepal_Length = mean(Sepal.Length),
    Mean_Sepal_Width = mean(Sepal.Width),
    Mean_Petal_Length = mean(Petal.Length),
    Mean_Petal_Width = mean(Petal.Width),
    Mean_Petal_Ratio = mean(Petal.Ratio)
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(Mean_Petal_Ratio))

kable(iris_statistics)

title: Example Analysis
text:
Data Visualization
After generating the table, we use ggplot2 package to plot some variables of interest and observe their distributions.

library(patchwork)

plot1 <- ggplot(iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Sepal Dimensions across Species",
    subtitle = "Sepal Length vs. Sepal Width",
    x = "Sepal Length (cm)",
    y = "Sepal Width (cm)",
    caption = "Data source: Iris Dataset from base R"
  ) +
  theme_classic()

plot2 <- ggplot(iris, aes(x = Petal.Length, y = Petal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Petal Dimensions across Species",
    subtitle = "Petal Length vs. Petal Width",
    x = "Petal Length (cm)",
    y = "Petal Width (cm)",
    caption = "Data source: Iris Dataset from base R"
  ) +
  theme_classic()

combined_plot <- plot1 + plot2 + 
                 plot_layout(guides = "collect") & theme(legend.position = "bottom")

combined_plot







ggplot(iris_summary, aes(x = Species, y = Petal.Ratio, fill = Species)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, width = 0.2) +
  geom_violin(alpha = 0.5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Petal Ratio across the three species",
    subtitle = "Boxplots with overlayed violin plots showing variation in petal ratios",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Petal Ratio (Length / Width)",
    caption = "Data source: Iris Dataset from base R"
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")







ggplot(iris_summary, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Petal.Ratio, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ Species) +
  labs(
    title = "Faceted Scatter Plot of Petal Dimensions by Species",
    subtitle = "Petal Length vs. Petal Width for each Species",
    x = "Sepal Length (cm)",
    y = "Petal Ratio (Petal Length / Petal Width)",
    caption = "Data source: Iris Dataset from base R"
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")














I used ggplot2::theme_classic() as the main theme of all of my plots, which is consistent with the Minimalism design of my website.

title: Example Analysis
text:
Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
Lastly, to perform dimension reduction and to let us better understand which set(s) of features contribute to the (principal) component and/or variation of the data points, I performed Principal Component Analysis (PCA) using the Iris dataset. Note that PCA only works for numeric data, so that we need to extract the numerical features from the dataset (unless perform data encoding for categorical features).

iris_numeric <- iris[, 1:4]
iris_pca <- prcomp(iris_numeric, center = TRUE, scale. = TRUE)
summary(iris_pca)

Importance of components:
                          PC1    PC2     PC3     PC4
Standard deviation     1.7084 0.9560 0.38309 0.14393
Proportion of Variance 0.7296 0.2285 0.03669 0.00518
Cumulative Proportion  0.7296 0.9581 0.99482 1.00000

pca_scores <- as.data.frame(iris_pca$x)
pca_scores$Species <- iris$Species

ggplot(pca_scores, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "PCA of Iris Dataset",
    x = "Principal Component 1",
    y = "Principal Component 2"
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")







loadings_df <- as.data.frame(iris_pca$rotation)
loadings_df$Variable <- rownames(loadings_df)

ggplot(loadings_df, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, label = Variable)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text(vjust = 0, hjust = 0.75) +
  labs(
    title = "PCA Loadings for Iris Dataset",
    x = "PC1 Loadings",
    y = "PC2 Loadings"
  ) +
  xlim(-0.4, 0.7) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Example Analysis
text:
Summary
From the plots and the tables, we can conclude that:

The three Iris species’ petal and sepal characteristics are so different that is well-separable. From the scatterplot, we can observe that setosa has shorter, wider sepals & tiny petals compared to the other two species. From the distribution we can deduce that setosa can be well-predicted, since the data points corresponds to this species have a clear boundary separating them from the rest of the group.
Iris setosa has a wide range of Petal.Ratio, whereas the rest of the two species exhibited dense and relative low Petal.Ratio statistics. Combined with the result of the first scatterplot, this suggest that both the widths and the lengths of the Iris setosa samples are more variable compared to the other two species.
Based on the third figure, the Sepal.Length of Iris versicolor and Iris virginica are more variable although their Petal.Ratio are consistent compared to Iris setosa. So we can conclude that the petal dimensions of Iris versicolor and Iris virginica are relatively consistent, but their sepal size tend to vary.
From the result of PCA, we can see that PC1 well-separated the Iris setosa from the rest of the two species. Iris virginica and Iris versicolor had a decent separation by PC1 with some overlaps. This visualization (finding) is consistent with the PCs summary statistics, where around \(73\%\) of the variation is explained by PC1. What factor contributes to the PC1? Based on the last plot showing the PCA loadings, we can see that Petal.Length and Petal.Width features are the two features that strongly influenced PC1. Considering PC1 is so important, this finding suggest that information about petal dimensions informed us the most about the species of Iris.

title: Example Analysis
text:
Function Used
dplyr package: mutate(), group_by(), summarize(), arrange(), desc().
ggplot2 package: geom_point(), geom_boxplot, geom_violin, facet_wrap().

title: Moran Guo
text: Hi there! I’m Moran Guo, you can also call me Raymond. As a graduate student, I’m passionate about all kinds of knowledge in the field of biostatistics, or broadly public health questions. I enjoy doing statistical analysis and solving statistical & mathematical problems; particularly, those theoretical methods attract me. Outside of academics, I am an active climber, intermediate (but passionate) chef, and currently looking forward to participate in hiking. I also love Japanese culture and I’ve obtained the JLPT N3 certificate. Feel free to chat with me about Riichi Majhong!
